definition: to seize/to take away forcibly/to wrest control of/to compete or strive for/to force one's way through/to leave out/to lose
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
a unit of length/inch/thumb
to take (after a struggle)/to wrest/to seize/to capture/to win (a trophy)
to fight over/to contest/to vie over
to seize the crown/fig. to win a championship/to win gold medal
to seize/to capture/to wrest control of
to deprive/to expropriate/to strip (sb of his property)
to plunder/to pillage/to forcibly take
struggle
to take back (forcibly)/to recapture/to win back
to snatch away
to plunder/to rob
to dazzle the eyes
to gain the upper hand by a show of strength
to seize/to win
to make a decision/to determine
to compete for first prize

sentences.english: Have you invited us here in order to impoverish us? Is it not so?
sentences.chinese: 难道你们请了我们来，是要夺我们所有的么？

sentences.english: I said, endeavoring to snatch the glass from his hand.
sentences.chinese: 我说，竭力想从他手里夺过杯子。

sentences.english: Thus God hath taken away the cattle of your father, and given them to me.
sentences.chinese: 这样，神把你们父亲的牲畜夺来赐给我了。

sentences.english: I hope you will take necessary precautions in packing this consignment.
sentences.chinese: 希望这次接货时对包装给夺必要的注意。

sentences.english: Arashi yao four sisters to seize the hand had excited was awake all night.
sentences.chinese: 岚么四姐妹为夺到手的军马兴奋的彻夜未眠。

sentences.english: Each soldier had taken plunder for himself.
sentences.chinese: 各兵丁都为自己夺了财物。

sentences.english: We must have effective control over the conquered landing place.
sentences.chinese: 我们必须对已夺的登陆场进行有效控制。

sentences.english: Olympics Begin In Style; Swimmer Takes 1st Gold.
sentences.chinese: 奥运会盛大揭幕泳将夺首枚金牌。

sentences.english: When the Israelites returned from chasing the Philistines, they plundered their camp.
sentences.chinese: 以色列人追赶非利士人回来，就夺了他们的营盘。

sentences.english: And the children of Israel returned from chasing after the Philistines, and they spoiled their tents.
sentences.chinese: 以色列人追赶非利士人回来，就夺了他们的营盘。

sentences.english: We are taking market shares from our competitors.
sentences.chinese: 我们正在从竞争对手那里夺来市场份额。

sentences.english: If someone takes your cloak, do not stop him from taking your tunic.
sentences.chinese: 有人夺你的外衣，连里衣也由他拿去。

sentences.english: I caught the cat from behind. I took the fish out of the cat's mouth.
sentences.chinese: 我从后面抓住了它，把鱼从它的嘴里夺了回来。

sentences.english: Han Army seized the car division, the Huns were also attacked cars Cavalry Division.
sentences.chinese: 汉军夺了车师，匈奴也派骑兵袭击车师。

sentences.english: He wrenched the bag from my hand.
sentences.chinese: 他猛地一下把包儿从我手中夺了过去。

sentences.english: They took their sheep, and their oxen, and their asses, and that which was in the city, and that which was in the field
sentences.chinese: 夺了他们的羊群，牛群，和驴，并城里田间所有的。

definition: to seize/to capture/to wrest control of
to snatch away
to snatch (esp related to a robbery)
to take back (forcibly)/to recapture/to win back
to plunder/to pillage/to forcibly take
to strive for/to vie for/to argue or debate/deficient or lacking (dialect)/how or what (literary)
to dip a finger (idiom); fig. to get one's finger in the pie/to get a share of the action/abbr. for 染指於鼎|染指于鼎
to covet/to long for/to lust after
to aspire to the throne/to aim at (the first place etc)
see 搶風|抢风[qiang1 feng1]
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
to take away
to dominate (a market etc)/to monopolize
to fight over/to contest/to vie over
to lose/to throw away/to discard/to cast away
to storm (a city etc)/to raid
(of property) to change owners/(of sovereignty, political power etc) to change hands
